content:
# Instructions:
You are an internal system that managers customer’s claims. Here is the list of the most common claims cases for airline companies. Each claim case has its code id, claim name, claim description and the amount due to the passenger, if applicable. There is also a list of important mandatory details that a customer should include when submitting a claim.

Claim cases:

1. Code LD - Luggage Delay: The luggage is delayed for more than 8 hours. A passenger is entitled to compensation for reasonable incidental expenses they incur because of their delayed baggage, up to the maximum liability limits, set by statute. 
airlines must pay the customer:
For domestic flights, this is $1,000 per passenger. 
For international flights, this is $1,500 per passenger.

2. Code LL - Lost Luggage: The luggage is lost. A passenger is entitled to compensation for reasonable incidental expenses they incur because of their lost baggage, up to the maximum liability limits, set by statute. 
airlines must pay the customer: up to $3,500 per passenger.

3. Code FDC - Flight Delay Controlled: The flight was delayed due to the circumstances within the airline's control, the passenger has been informed of the delay less than 12 hours before the departure time on their original ticket, and they have waited at the airport for 4 hours or more after the departure time on your original ticket. 
Those circumstances are limited to: Maintenance issues, Crew scheduling problems, Logistical delays, Ground operations Issues.
airlines must pay the customer:
$400 if a customer arrives late at their destination by 3 hours or more, but less than 6 hours
$700 if a customer arrives late at their destination by 6 hours or more, but less than 9 hours

4. Code FDFM - Flight Delay force majeure: a passenger is not entitled to any compensation if the flight was delayed due to the circumstances that are not within the airline's control:
a) Weather conditions: severe weather such as thunderstorms, hurricanes, snowstorms, or dense fog can lead to airport closures, air traffic restrictions, and ultimately flight delays.
b) Security Issues - Unplanned security-related incidents or threats at an airport may lead to temporary closures, resulting in delays for affected flights.
c) Natural disasters - Events such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, or tsunamis can disrupt air travel infrastructure and lead to flight delays.

Mandatory details (slots) to be provided with every claim submitted:
[Passenger’s Name]
[Passenger’s Contact Information]
 reservation # 
 ticket#
airline_name 
flight #
arrival_city 
departure_city 
notification_date (“n/a” if for Code LD, Code LL )
notification_time (“true” only for Code CF, Code DF, Code FDFM, (“n/a” if for Code LD, Code LL)
delay_period (in hours) (“n/a” for Code LL)

Using the information provided in the customer request (the utterance below) your task will be to determine the type of the customer’s claim. 
When answering use code Ids and extract all relevant slots and their values. If multiple slots are provided, fill all the slots. If a slot value is not provided, set the value of the slot to "none".

Return your answer in json.

# The utterance:

"Hey! worst experience ever!!  Upon arrival to my final destination from a business trip, I discovered that my suitcase did not arrived with my flight. The bag contains some collectible items and very expensive watches! What will I do now?! contact me ASAP!"
